More Notes: Baseline model result. Equivalent to losing the last 7 years of productivity growth.
More severe impacts in warmer regions
The impact of anthropogenic climate change on global agricultural Total Factor Productivity (TFP) growth over the period 1961-2020.
The average mean impact of anthropogenic climate change (ACC) is reported to be -16.9% with a standard deviation of 5.9%.
The damage is said to be larger in the latter part of the sample (1989-2015), pointing to a reduction on the order of -30%.
ACC impact since 1961 is greater for Africa at -34.0%.
ACC impact since 1961 is -30.0% for the Near East and North Africa.
ACC impact since 1961 is -25.9% for Latin America and the Caribbean.
ACC impact since 1961 is -12.5% for North America.
ACC impact since 1961 is -7.1% for Europe and Central Asia.
Global output is expected to be reduced by -27.6% with a 90% confidence interval between -48.3% and -14.3%.
Average mean impact of 288 models that do not exclude observations, plus and minus a standard deviation.
